column52: Queenborough & Rushenden – Twyford Demolition and Enabling Works
column53:
Queenborough and Rushenden is a major development site within the HCA’s Economic Assets Programme and a key component of the Kent and Medway Stewardship Plan. The HCA have also acquired the Klondyke site, and together with the Twyfords site represents a total of 20 hectares to be brought forward for mixed-use regeneration. In conjunction with the Caradon site to the south, these sites will provide 2,000 new homes and circa 180,000m2 of employment space on the Isle of Sheppey in North Kent.

Tenders are being sought from specialist Contractors to undertake the following works on the Twyford site:

Core Works
•	Site set up and welfare facilities.
•	Demolition of The Gateway building and adjacent building down to ground slab and removal / disposal of all asbestos, including approximately 200m3 of asbestos contaminated soils to the rear of The Gateway. 
•	Disconnection / termination of private utilities to site boundary. 
•	Ecological supervision to monitor for nesting birds in buildings to be demolished. 
•	Facilitate and maintain access for material haulage to Invicta Merchant Bar site. 

Additional Works
•	Remediation of remaining hotspot of contamination on ‘SLR2’ in accordance with the agreed Hydrock Remediation Strategy and CampbellReith Remediation Specification.
•	Ground slab removal, crushing and ground obstruction removal of ‘UKPN HV cable corridor’ (cable already diverted) and ‘SLR2’ area.
•	Reuse of site-won concrete to form a drainage blanket and piling mat.

Additional information: The closing time for tenders is 1pm.

The Invitation to Tender, Tender Return Label and Pricing Schedule can be downloaded from this notice.  All other supporting  documentation can be found at https://upload.hca-online.org.uk/tenders/hcap16068/hcap16068.zip

All discussions, meetings and communications will be conducted in English.  

The contract will be subject to English law.  Tenders and all supporting documents must be priced in GBP and all payments under the contract will be made in GBP.

Contractors must be licensed by the HSE and also be members of the Asbestos Removal Contractors Association (ARCA). In addition to ARCA we also recognise ACAD (Asbestos Control & Abatement Division).

This procurement and award is subject to the transparency arrangements being adopted by the UK Government. These arrangements include the publication of tender documentation issued by the HCA and the contract between the HCA and supplier.  Bidders should highlight any areas they consider commercially sensitive in order for the HCA to be able to honour our transparency obligations without undermining the bidders commercial interests.

Candidates are advised that the HCA is subject to the Freedom of Information Act 2000 ("The Act"). If a candidate considers that any of the information supplied as part of this procurement procedure should not be disclosed because of its commercial sensitivity, confidential or otherwise, they must, when providing this information, clearly identify the specific information they do not wish to be disclosed and clearly specify the reasons for its sensitivity. The HCA shall take such statements into consideration in the event that it receives a request pursuant to the Act which relates to the information provided by the interested party. Please note, it is insufficient to include a statement of confidentiality encompassing all the information provided in the response.

The HCA takes a zero-tolerance approach to bribery and corruption and sets high standards of impartiality, integrity and objectivity in relation to the stewardship of public funds and the management of its activities. The principles contained within this policy apply to both internal and external audiences, including anyone wishing to undertake business or engage with the HCA. Please refer to our Anti-bribery and Corruption Policy by visiting https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/anti-bribery-and-corruption-policy for further information.

NHS Central London Clinical Commissioning Group (the Commissioner), acting as Lead Commissioner on behalf of itself, Hammersmith & Fulham Clinical Commissioning Group and West London Clinical Commissioning Group, together with London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham, Westminster City Council and Royal Borough of Kensington & Chelsea are presently finalising their strategy for commissioning an integrated Community Independence Service (CIS) and is undertaking market engagement in order to seek the views and opinions of those organisations that may be interested in helping to deliver one or more of the following services: 

• Rapid response 
• In-reach/ supported discharge 
• Rehabilitation 
• Reablement 

The CCG is inviting interested parties to engage with it on the future provision of these services with a view to seeking input and feedbackto help inform the CCG as it considers its requirements and routes to market. 

The above services are part of a number of intermediate care services available to patients, currently being delivered by various providers. 

NHS England has made a commitment to developing a coherent 24/7 urgent care service in every area of England that makes sense to patients when having to make choices about care and to drive the integration of services. It also committed to the provision of integrated NHS services seven days a week in order that patients experience genuine seven day care. It is expected that better integration will be delivered through: 

- Improved communications within and between service providers; 
- Improved coordination of services; 
- Reduced duplication of services and activities. 

A draft Memorandum of Information (MoI) and current service specification are available for review, being attached to this Notice for download. An engagement questionnaire has also been developed to capture input from providers to help inform the CCG’s key decisions around these services. You are invited to respond to the questionnaire and return to us by the deadline below.

The current contract value relating to the above services is expected to total circa £22,700,000 over the life of the  contract. If the CCG decides to undertake a formal procurement process then this is anticipated to commence in February 2016 through a notice on Contracts Finder, with the intention to have a contract(s) awarded by the end of April 2016 and for services to commence in July 2016. The integrated CIS will commence in July 2016, other services may follow later in the contract. 

***Providers are invited to express their interest in the early engagement via emailing the completed questionnaire to anne.elgeti@nw.london.nhs.uk THE DEADLINE FOR SUBMISSIONS is 25th JANUARY 2016.***

Additional information: Note: An expression of interest is no indication of a commitment to participate in any subsequent procurement process, nor does it infer any special status on those providers who do submit an interest. Neither will this notice or any organisation’s expression of interest commit the CCG to undertake any procurement of the Community Independence Service or other Intermediate Care services & the CCG has a right to withdraw the notice. 

The CCG’s ambition is to combine services across geographies to improve lives and make public funds go further for the people we serve. In common with the rest of England, they are experiencing an unprecedented period of growing demands on current services, with limited resources to meet these demands.

column52: Spine Remodelling Project
column53:
The Spine provides a continuous pedestrian walkway for students, staff and visitors running the length of the Lancaster University Campus. Part of the original 1960s design, the Spine affords a partially covered route giving access to the principal academic buildings along with retail and service facilities. An accessible utility duct runs beneath the full length of the Spine. 
The University is currently celebrating its 50th year and occupies a position in the top 100 universities in the world. In order maintain that position and to provide facilities appropriate to the 21st century, Lancaster University seeks to remodel and upgrade the Spine to provide a vibrant, light, safe, weather protected route, offering a variety of environments along its length, reinforcing its identity as the main Campus thoroughfare.

Bidders are asked to submit their tenders based on two possible options:

Option A: A single construction phase commencing in July 2016, completing in July 2017
for both the North and South Spine. This option is reliant on the University obtaining the necessary funding for phase 2. Please note Lancaster University will not commit itself to this package of works and reserves the right to award a single contract for phase 1 

Option B: Two construction phases commencing in July 2016

•	Phase 1 – The North Spine (Alexandra Square northwards) 2016-2017.
•	Phase 2 – The South Spine (South of Alexandra Square) 2017-2018.
Contractor input in phasing and buildability advice will be sought and will be critical to the success of the project. A major consideration will be how best to minimise disturbance to the regular business of the University by the use of innovative construction techniques, off site preparation and prefabrication. This may allow extended access for work during term times.

column53:
3 CCGs in South Staffordshire, led by NHS Stafford and Surrounds Clinical Commissioning Group, are seeking to re-procure the current provision of Non Obstetric Ultrasound services through AQP. The associate CCGs are Cannock Chase Clinical Commissioning Group and South East Staffordshire and Seisdon Peninsular Clinical Commissioning Group. This is a full re-opening of the current AQP Non Obstetric Ultrasound service. All existing providers must reapply for accreditation status to continue providing this service as at 1.4.2016. Please note that under ‘Any Qualified Provider’ contracts there will be no guarantees of volume in the contracts awarded. Further, prices are set and can be accessed on the tariff (included in the documentation?).
The overarching aims of the service are:
— to ensure patients receive the right test at the right time and in the most clinically appropriate local setting,
— to ensure diagnostic testing is integrated across pathways of care, that the report and/or images follows the patient and that there is no unnecessary duplication of investigation,
— to enable patients and referring clinicians to access a choice of provision according to patient choice, clinical need and relevant care pathway, and
— to ensure diagnostic tests are appropriate, necessary, clinically correct, of high quality, with timely access and reporting,
— to develop local service provision as part of a diagnostic commissioning plan which aims to improve access and choice for patients.
The service will be commissioned using the Any Qualified Provider process. In securing services under the AQP process, assurance of competence, quality and safety standards is required. Any provider will be eligible to join the Qualified Provider list subject to demonstrating competency against specified criteria. Qualified providers will be expected to deliver the service under the NHS Standard Contract. As a Qualified Provider there are no guaranteed levels of activity and payment is made based on actual provision. Specification for carrying out works to remove scrub on  116 ha Thorne and Hatfield Moor formerly milled peat workings near Doncaster, South Yorkshire 

The Humberhead Peatlands are the UK’s largest lowland raised bog complex in the UK.  They are designated under the EU Habitats and Birds Directives as part of the Natura 2000 network of sites. The “Restoring Humberhead Peatlands: LIFE+ Project” (THAT’S LIFE) aims to restore the bogs of Thorne Moors Special Area of Conservation (SAC) and Hatfield Moors SAC to allow the sites to achieve favourable SAC status; to increase the population of breeding Nightjars on the Thorne and Hatfield Moors Special Protection Area (SPA) and; to work with local communities to increase awareness of the importance of these sites.
